Graphical abstract Controlling selective glycerol electrooxidation towards the primary or secondary alcohol group, which enables obtained dihydroxyacetone or glyceraldehyde as the main product, is a challenge for an effective glycerol electrolysis system. In this work, we systematically investigated the protective effect of borate-glycerol complexes toward primary and secondary alcohol group oxidation during the glycerol electrooxidation process on NiOx catalyst in borate buffer (pH 9.2). The Raman spectroscopy and high-performance liquid chromatography results indicated that manipulating the borate/glycerol (B/G) ratio could affect selective oxidation towards primary or secondary alcohol group. Five-member ring complex was more likely to form in the electrolyte with the B/G ratio of 0.1, whereas six-member ring complex became more significant in the electrolyte with the B/G ratio of 1.5. The dominance of five- or six-member ring complex could enhance the favored adsorption of primary or secondary alcohol group, thus generating glyceraldehyde or dihydroxyacetone as the main product, respectively. The results in this study highlight the significance of electrolyte property on glycerol electrocatalysis, which is universally applicable to other transition metal electrocatalysts, enabling the development of a highly selective glycerol electrooxidation towards primary or secondary alcohol system at near-neutral pH level. Keywords Glycerol electrooxidation Borate/glycerol ratio Dihydroxyacetone Glyceraldehyde In-situ Raman spectroscopy Data availability Data will be made available upon reasonable request 1 Introduction Increasing energy demand for industrialization, transportation, and the development of science and technology have driven the exploration of alternative and sustainable energy sources. For example, biodiesel has been classified as a renewable, biodegradable, non-toxic, environment-friendly source, and a potential replacement for fossil fuels [1–3]. The biodiesel manufacturer co-generates 10 % weight of glycerol as a by-product, which far outweighs current glycerol demand and consequently negatively impacts the biodiesel economy [3]. An interest in combining hydrogen generation and electro-valorization of cheap biomass feedstock has recently opened a promising approach for converting glycerol to various valuable products and boosting biodiesel profit. Depending on the nature of electrocatalysts and working conditions, various highly valuable three-carbon (3C) products, including dihydroxyacetone, glyceraldehyde, glyceric acid, tartronic acid, and mesoxalic acid, could be obtained [4–8]. Nearly every oxygenated product derived from glycerol upgrading is more valuable than glycerol itself and is in high demand on the global market. Establishing an electrochemical route for a highly selective and efficient glycerol electrooxidation process (GEOR) to desirable 3C products is essential for expanding their worldwide commercial size. In most previous studies, low-value-added products, such as formic acid and carbon dioxide, were obtained as major products when performing glycerol electrooxidation reaction (GEOR) in strong alkaline media [9,10]. Improving a versatile GEOR electrolysis system that can generate valuable products is thus critical to the general adoption of this approach. In recent reports, the electrocatalytic performance of various metal oxide electrocatalysts, including CuO [11], MnO2 [12,13], CoOx [7,14], Co3O4 [15], NiOOH [10], yolk@shell structure Au@NiSx [16], Cu2O [17] toward GEOR in near neutral media was conducted. Highly valuable products, dihydroxyacetone (DHA), glyceraldehyde (GLYD), and other three-carbon products, could be obtained, demonstrating the application of GEOR in fine chemical synthesis. In addition, DHA and GLYD are unstable in strong basic media and easily convert to other chemicals spontaneously [11,12]. Therefore, investigating GEOR at near-neutral pH, where all products are stable, is essential for precisely evaluating the ability to produce three-carbon products of catalysts. Structurally, glycerol contains three functional –OH groups, two primary and one secondary, which makes it impossible to insulate one functional group from oxidation occurring at another. Two first oxidation products of GEOR, glyceraldehyde (GLYD), and dihydroxyacetone (DHA) which originate from oxidizing primary and secondary alcohol groups, respectively, are identified as valuable targets. Selective oxidation of the secondary alcohol group is much more challenging than the primary one due to steric hindrance [18,19]. In addition, vicinal hydroxyl groups in glycerol facilitate the undesired C–C bond breakage in alkaline media, forming two-carbon and one-carbon products [20,21]. Therefore, to achieve high selectivity towards DHA or GLYD, the major challenge is protecting the other two –OH groups while oxidation occurs at the target –OH group. On the other hand, borate and boronate ester have been used for the preferential protection of particular pairs of hydroxy groups within poly-hydroxylated compounds and thus provide selective access to organic and inorganic esters, carbamates, ethers, and disaccharides [22–25]. In a recent report, sodium borate, capable of forming anionic coordination complexes with glycerol, was employed as the mild alkaline electrolyte and hence successfully enhanced activity and selectivity towards DHA during GEOR [26]. However, there is ongoing debate regarding the favorable oxidation of the secondary alcohol group of glycerol. In addition, the complex formation was affected by borate to glycerol ratio [27–29], hence it is expected to have impacts on GEOR activity and selectivity of the target product. This calls for more inquiry into the further understanding of GEOR in the borate buffer. As for non-noble metal electrocatalysts, Ni-based ones have gained the most extensive attraction and have been successfully applied in many fields, such as water splitting, glycerol electrooxidation, and batteries [9,10,16,30–34]. The well-known active layer of Ni-based catalyst is NiOOH, which possesses the ability to oxidize the alcohol group to corresponding ketone and carboxylic acid [9,10,16]. Very recently, Ni0 has been reported as the active site for GEOR, suggesting the active site of Ni-based catalyst was not confined to NiOOH species [35]. The essence of the electrode function mechanism at in-working conditions remains debatable. Although commonly observed Raman bands of NiOOH species under working conditions, the origin of the broadening band around 900 – 1200 cm−1 is still unclear [31,36,37]. Based on the abovementioned discussion, this study investigates the effect of borate-polyol chelate on three-carbon product generation during GEOR over NiOx catalyst in borate buffer. Moreover, the in-situ Raman spectroscopy was employed to measure catalytic properties under working conditions, especially for the Raman feature around 900 – 1200 cm−1, which was hardly explored previously. Based on high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) and Raman spectroscopy, we additionally discuss how varying borate and glycerol concentration could formulate glycerol oxidation conditions on NiOx to control the selective oxidation process on primary and secondary alcohol groups, hence control selectivity towards GLYD and DHA, respectively. Our comprehensive study on GEOR enables the strategy of controlling oxidation on the target alcohol group through manipulating borate-glycerol coordination chelate, maximizing selectivity towards DHA or GLYD on the non-precious catalyst NiOx in borate buffer. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation The amorphous NiOx catalyst was prepared using a photochemical metal–organic deposition process with some modifications, as described in previous reports [38,39]. Generally, a solution containing n-hexane (95 %, Sigma Alrich) and 15 % wt nickel (II) ethyl hexanoate (78 %, Sigma Alrich) was mixed for 15 min using sonication. The resultant homogeneous solution was then spin-coated on 1 cm2 fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) substrate (2500 rpm, 8 s) and irradiated for 36 h under ultraviolet light (λ = 254 nm). Afterward, these samples were annealed at 100 °C for 1 h to remove all remaining organic compounds. The fabrication process is illustrated in Fig. 1 . 2.2 Catalyst characterization The crystal structure of the as-prepared electrode was first measured using X-ray diffractometer (XRD, D2 Bruker, US) with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.15405 nm) at a scan rate of 0.1° s−1. The sample morphology was determined using scanning electron microscopy (JEOL JSM-6500F, Japan). Raman spectra were recorded with a microscopical confocal Raman spectrometer (MRID, Protrustech, Taiwan) using 532 nm laser excitation. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy spectrum was measured using X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (ESCALAB 250, VG Scientific) with Al X-ray radiation. The binding energy of C 1 s (284.8 eV) was used to calibrate XPS spectra. In order to detect the adsorption behavior of glycerol on the catalyst surfaces, the reflectance spectra of these electrodes were recorded using Fourier-transform infrared spectrometer (FTIR, Tracer-100, Shimadzu). Before conducting the FTIR measurement, the activated electrode was immersed in electrolytes containing different glycerol concentrations overnight and then dried with N2 flow. 2.3 Electrocatalytic activity evaluation and product analysis Linear sweep voltammetric and chronoamperometric measurements were conducted using a three-electrode setup in a two-compartment cell separated by a Nafion membrane. NiOx electrode (geometry area of 1 cm2), a carbon rod, and an Ag/AgCl (3 M KCl) were working, counter, and reference electrodes, respectively. The mild alkaline supporting electrolyte (0.1 M Na2B4O7 or 0.1 M NaHCO3 solution with pH of 9.2) was chosen to prevent the isomerization of glyceraldehyde/ dihydroxyacetone and the degradation of these products. The GEOR activity of NiOx sample was first examined in two pH 9.2 electrolytes (borate buffer and carbonate buffer) with and without 0.1 M glycerol. 15 mL of electrolyte with and without glycerol were added in the anodic and cathodic side of the two-compartment cell, respectively. Before conducting GEOR, the activation step was performed by sweeping cyclic voltammetry from 1.2 to 1.95 VRHE with the scan rate of 50 mV s−1. After 100 CV scans, the voltammograms of NiOx sample became stabilized ( Supporting information , Fig. S1 ). The catalyst employed for all electrochemical investigations was the activated sample, unless stated otherwise. The voltammetric experiment was swept from 1.0 VRHE to 2.05 VRHE in pH 9.2 electrolyte at a scan rate of 20 mV s−1. The glycerol electrooxidation was carried out at various constant potentials (1.55, 1.75, and 1.95 VRHE) at room temperature under a mild stirring condition. To evaluate the chelating effect of glycerol and borate on GEOR, fixed 0.1 M borate buffer containing various glycerol concentrations or fixed 0.1 M glycerol added to various concentrations of borate buffer were used as reaction electrolytes. The pH of these electrolytes was adjusted to pH 9.2 using 3 M NaOH or 3 M H2SO4 solution. All the potentials were reported versus reversible hydrogen electrodes (RHE). Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) spectra were conducted in the same electrolyte with the voltammetric experiment at an overpotential of 200 mV, respecting the onset potential of each electrolyte, ranging from 105 to 10-2 Hz. During the glycerol electrooxidation process, 25 μL liquid samples were taken from the working electrode chamber hourly and analyzed using high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC, Young Lin YL-9100, Korea) equipped with an ion-exchange column (RCM-Monosaccharide Ca+2, Phenomenex). An aqueous mobile phase, 0.5 mM H2SO4 with a flow rate of 0.5 mL/min, was used in isocratic mode. The column temperature was set at 70 °C. The product selectivity, carbon balance and Faradic efficiency were calculated based on the number of moles of all products (refer to Supporting information , Experimental section, and Table S1 for details). The standards used in this work were HPLC grade, including glycerol (J.T. Baker, ≥ 99.5 %), dihydroxyacetone (Sigma-Aldrich, 98 %), DL-glyceraldehyde (Sigma-Aldrich, 90 %), tartronic acid (Alfa Aesar, 98 %), DL-glyceric acid (TCI, 20 % in water), glycolic acid (Acros Organic, 99 %), formic acid (Acros Organic, 99 %). 2.4 In-situ tracking phase-evolution using Raman spectroscopy In-situ Raman measurement was performed using a confocal Raman microscope (MRID, ProTrusTech Co., Taiwan) with a 50 × object lens and the excitation of 532 nm laser. The electrochemical test was conducted in a homemade acrylic cell with borate buffer containing 0.1 M glycerol. Three electrodes, a NiOx electrode, a carbon rod, and an Ag/AgCl (3 M KCl) were working, counter, and reference electrodes, respectively. Before conducting in-situ Raman spectroscopy, the NiOx catalyst was activated until reaching the stable cyclic voltammogram. Potential-dependent Raman spectroscopy was performed at three potentials, 1.55, 1.65, and 1.75 VRHE, and the spectra were recorded every 10 min during 1 h GEOR (with an exposure time of 30 s and accumulation time of 20 times). The spectra were smoothed using the Savitzky-Golay method and fitted with the Lorentzian functions using OriginPro 2023 software (OriginLab Corporation, USA). 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Potential-dependent GEOR and surface reconstruction of NiOx catalyst in borate buffer The crystal structure, morphology, and surface properties of NiOx sample were evaluated by XRD, Raman spectroscopy, and XPS. As shown in Fig. 2 a, only peaks belonging to FTO were observed, and the XRD pattern of the NiOx sample showed no peak of nickel species, indicated its XRD amorphous property. To get further insight into the surface property of NiOx sample, Raman spectroscopy and XPS were conducted. As disclosed in Fig. 2 b, the Raman spectrum of the NiOx sample showed Raman peaks of NiO at 466, 558, 786, 940, 1090 cm−1, α-Ni(OH)2 at 367, 910, 980, 1045 cm−1 and β-Ni(OH)2 at 435, 500, 598, 670, and 875 cm−1. It was suggested that the first-order LO phonon scattering at 551 cm−1 occurring in NiO may be due to nickel vacancy defects or the presence of Ni3+ [40,41]. Therefore, the sharp and highly intense peak at 551 cm−1 could be due to the presence of Ni3+ in the sample. The Ni 2p XPS spectrum depicted in Fig. 2 c was deconvoluted into two doublet peaks along with two shake-up satellite peaks (denoted as “Sat.”). The peak at 855.6 eV belonged to Ni2+, and the peak at 856.9 eV was assigned to Ni3+, further confirming the existence of Ni3+ in surface composition. In addition, the O 1 s spectra illustrated in Fig. 2 d were fitted into three peaks. One peak centered at 529.7 eV corresponded to oxygen bonding Ni (Olattice), the other peak at 531.2 eV belonged to oxygen defect (Odefect), and the peak centered at 532.6 eV was ascribed to physisorbed and chemisorbed water at or near the surface of the samples [42,43]. The GEOR on non-noble electrocatalysts has been widely studied in the strong alkaline media (pH 13 or higher) with 0.1 M glycerol, resulting in obtaining FA as the major product [9,11,44,45]. It should be noted that DHA and GLYD were not stable in strong alkaline media ( Fig. S2 ), which could decompose to other chemicals, hindering the presence of these products during GEOR. Therefore, the electrocatalytic activity of NiOx towards glycerol oxidation was evaluated in pH 9.2 electrolyte (0.1 M Na2B4O7) with and without the presence of 0.1 M glycerol. Apparently, the NiOx exhibited a relatively low current density in the electrolyte with the absence of glycerol, while the increase in current density and negative shift of onset potential could be observed in the electrolyte containing 0.1 M glycerol, suggesting that NiOx preferred GEOR over OER (Fig. 3 a). To evaluate the GEOR activity of the NiOx catalyst, 3 h continuous chronoamperometry at three constant potentials (1.55, 1.75, and 1.95 VRHE) in borate buffer was recorded as the function of reaction time. As illustrated in Fig. 3 b, the NiOx sample showed a stable current during 3 h test in all investigated potentials. After 3 h reaction, the crystal structure, morphology, and surface composition of the post-GEOR sample remained almost unchanged compared to the as-prepared sample ( Figs. S3-S4 ), confirming the good stability of the NiOx catalyst. The effect of applied potential on liquid products in borate buffer was illustrated in Fig. 3 c-d. The chromatograms for three applied potentials in Fig. S5 indicated that six products were detected, including DHA, GLYD, glyceric acid (GLAC), tartronic acid (TART), glycolic acid (GLCO), and formic acid (FA). As shown in Fig. 3 c-d, the selectivity of 3C product was maintained at around 80 % for all applied potentials, while the amount of product increased steadily along with an increase in external bias. The increase in applied potential had minimal influence on DHA selectivity, accounting for around 40 % of all investigated potentials. In contrast, GLYD exhibited a downward trend of selectivity, which accounted for 43.5 % at 1.55 VRHE, and decreased steadily to 31.7 % at 1.95 VRHE. GLCO and TART, products originated from further oxidation of GLYD, would be observed with a limited amount (from 3 to 9 %) at 1.75 and 1.95 VRHE, indicating that high applied potential caused serious C–C bonds breakage or driving deeper oxidation process. In addition, the time-dependent HPLC analysis in Fig. S6 indicated that extending the reaction time would result in a higher yield of product but cause a slight change in product distribution. The Faradaic efficiency (FE) for liquid products as the function of potential was calculated and summarized in Table S2 . Overall, with the increase in applied potential, the total FE of GEOR decreased rapidly, from ∼ 100 % at 1.55 VRHE to 56 % at 1.95 VRHE, suggesting OER could occur when the applied potential is higher than 1.55 VRHE. When the applied potential increased from 1.55 to 1.95 VRHE, the FE of DHA, GLYD, and FA dropped rapidly from 36 to 14.1 %, from 38.2 to 9.4 %, and from 22.4 to 8.4 %, respectively. Meanwhile, the FE of GLAC and TART were found to be slightly increasing along with an increase in applied potential. We found that the carbon balance slightly decreased along with an increase in potential, accounting for 96.4 % at 1.95 VRHE, suggesting a low probability of intermediates escaping from the sampling and analysis of HPLC. To further study the dynamic compositional evolution and unravel the active species of NiOx toward GEOR, in-situ Raman spectroscopy analysis was conducted at three potentials, including 1.55, 1.65, and 1.75 VRHE. It is important to note that the spectra were collected at potentials less than 1.8 VRHE to avoid gas bubble formation that might interfere with the laser irradiation, and cause noise and signal attenuation. The open circuit potential (OCP) spectra reflected the characteristic spectra of NiO, α-Ni(OH)2, and β-Ni(OH)2, in accordance with the ex-situ spectra of the sample in Fig. 2 b. As disclosed in the right panel of Fig. 4 , when applying potential, the significant transformation occurred in both spectral shape and intensity at 470, 550, and 1090 cm−1, reflecting the surface reconstruction of the NiOx sample. After a 50 min reaction, the shape and intensity of in-situ Raman spectra did not change, suggesting that the reconstruction process reached a stable state. Hence, the Lorentz fitting then was applied for the spectra collected at 60 min to analyze in-working surface composition. The 60 min spectra were fitted and displayed in the right panel of Fig. 4, and the peak assignment was briefly summarized in Table S3 . When the potential reached 1.55 VRHE, two new emerging peaks at 470 and 545 cm−1, which represented Eg bending vibration (δ(Ni–O)) and A1g stretching vibration (ν (Ni–O)) modes of γ-NiOOH [32,46], occurred. Meanwhile, the disappearance of NiO band 466 cm−1, and the attenuation of NiO bands (565, 780, 940, and 1087 cm−1) [47,48], α-Ni(OH)2 bands (372, 907, 981, and 1045 cm−1) [30,49,50], and β-Ni(OH)2 bands (440, 500, 607, 659, and 875 cm−1) [30,50] were observed. This observation indicated that the conversion from NiO/Ni(OH)2 to γ-NiOOH happened from 1.55 VRHE. When further increasing potential to 1.75 VRHE, two bands of γ-NiOOH became intensified while NiO, α-Ni(OH)2, and β-Ni(OH)2 bands became less pronounced, suggesting that the conversion from NiO/Ni(OH)2 to high-valance γ-NiOOH species became more significant at high applied potential, and γ-NiOOH species could act as the active site for GEOR. Although commonly observed in Ni-based OER catalysts, the origin of the broadband around 900 – 1200 remains debatable [31,36,51]. Some have been assigned to a NiOOH species at the surface [31,51], while others ascribed them to oxygen atoms O0 (1/2O2) or peroxide species [37,52,53]. It should be noted that several peaks at about 910, 940, 980, 1045, and 1090 cm−1 were observed already at the 1.55 VRHE spectra. The appearance of such a broad feature at 1.55 VRHE spectra of NiOx (before OER), therefore, was attributed to a lattice transformation instead of the formation of an active oxygen intermediate. Our findings indicated that the decrease in intensity of the broadband at 900 – 1200 cm−1 was due to the transformation from NiO, α-Ni(OH)2, and β-Ni(OH)2 to NiOOH species, which is in line with previous reports [31,54]. At high potentials, owing to the formation of the high content of Ni3+ with strong oxidation ability as dominant components, the NiOx electrocatalyst was capable of oxidizing both –OH and –C=O groups, generating DHA, GLYD, and other products. Regardless of the nature of the catalyst and applied potential, GEOR in fixed electrolyte composition (0.1 M Na2B4O7 solution with 0.1 M glycerol) yielded high selectivity toward 3C product (around 80 %) and generated DHA as the main product [10,12,14,17,26]. Compared to GEOR in borate buffer, the GEOR in carbonate buffer (0.1 M NaHCO3, pH 9.2) resulted in lower current density, 3C product selectivity, and amount of 3C products ( Fig. S7 ). For instance, at 1.75 VRHE, the selectivity for FA, GLYD, and DHA were 30.8 %, 36.5 %, and 12.9 % in carbonated buffer, and 20.7 %, 29.6 %, and 35.4 % in borate buffer, respectively, suggesting the lower C–C bond breakage and selective oxidation of secondary alcohol group in borate buffer, consistent with previous reports [10,26]. This phenomenon was attributed to the formation of the borate-glycerol coordination complex [26]. Furthermore, altering the concentrations of borate and glycerol resulted in a shift in the equilibrium of borate-glycerol complex formation [28,29], potentially affecting the activity and selectivity of the target product in GEOR. Hence, the next section will assess the impact of the borate to glycerol ratio on GEOR, a factor that has not been examined before. 3.2 Controlling oxidation towards the primary or secondary alcohol group by tuning borate/glycerol ratio Borate is a weak base, and the chelate between borate and glycerol could be affected by tuning pH of solution, borate and glycerol concentration. A complex solution equilibrium is likely to exist between the various possible borate esters [27,55]. Varying borate and glycerol concentrations could impact borate-glycerol complexes and, hence, are expected to affect GEOR performance and product distribution. It should be noted that the highest borate concentration was fixed at 0.15 M because of the limited solubility of Na2B4O7 at room temperature. The effect of borate concentration (0.01, 0.05, 0.10, and 0.15 M) on GEOR was first investigated using borate electrolytes (pH 9.2) with fixed glycerol concentration at 0.1 M, and the J-E curves were plotted in Fig. 5 a. As shown in Fig. 5 a, NiOx exhibited similar onset potentials (around 1.55 VRHE) under different borate concentration electrolytes. The increase in borate concentration led to higher current density which might be due to the buffer capacity of borate buffer. The OH– species is involved in almost all steps of the GEOR process, hence the pH value of the electrolyte and local pH close to the electrode play an essential role in determining the GEOR activity of the electrode [56]. The higher the borate concentration, the better the buffer capacity of the electrolyte is. Meanwhile, the redox process of Ni2+/Ni3+ is associated with the consumption of OH– on the catalyst surface to generate NiOOH species, according to the following reaction: Ni(OH)2 + OH–→ NiOOH+H2O+e– [57], suggesting that the formation of Ni3+ species could be facilitated if local pH near electrode was maintained. Therefore, the increase in borate concentration could enhance maintaining the local pH near the electrode, which promote the formation of Ni3+, and hence enhance the catalytic activity of NiOx. To limit the inaccurate qualitative analysis due to low signal intensity derived from low concentration of liquid products, the applied potential of 1.75 VRHE was chosen for further investigation. The liquid product analysis for 3 h GEOR at 1.75 VRHE was conducted in four borate concentrations (0.01, 0.05, 0.10, 0.15 M) (Fig. 5 b and S8-9). In all cases, three major products were DHA, GLYD, and FA, while three minor products, TART, GLAC, and GLCO, were generated with a lower selectivity (<10 %). It is obvious that borate concentration governed the product distribution and the amount of the product with the prolonged reaction time. As displayed in Fig. 5 b, the selectivity towards 3C products went up steadily along with the increase in borate concentration and reached a maximum selectivity of ∼ 80 % at a borate concentration of 0.15 M. In particular, when increasing borate concentration from 0.01 to 0.15 M, the selectivity of FA decreased gradually from 36.3 to around 17.3 %, whereas selectivity of DHA exhibited an upward trend and DHA became a primary product with selectivity of ∼ 40.2 % in 0.15 M borate electrolyte. Interestingly, the rise of borate concentration was accompanied by an increase in deeper oxidation products, namely GLAC and GLCO. The selectivity of GLAC and GLCO increase gradually from 2.5 to 11.2 %, and from 0.8 % to 1.2 % when increasing borate concentration from 0.01 to 0.15 M, respectively. These findings implied that utilizing high borate concentration could limit the C–C bond cleavage, resulting in higher 3C product selectivity. The change in Faradic efficiency (FE) for GEOR in different borate concentrations was illustrated in Fig. 5 c and Table S4 . The total FE fluctuated with varying borate concentrations, accounting for 61.2, 51.6, 58.5, and 59.2 % in 0.01, 0.05, 0.1, and 0.15 M borate electrolytes, respectively. In particular, the FE for FA decreased steadily from 25.3 to 11.9 %, while the FE for DHA increased from 11.8 % to 20.7 % when increasing borate concentration from 0.01 to 0.15 M. Again, the FE for GLAC, TART, and GLCO found went up steadily and accounted for 12.4, 5.6 and 0.6 % in 0.15 M borate buffer. The above data demonstrated that utilizing high borate concentration made GEOR more effective, protecting DHA and GLYD from C-C cleavage. More importantly, the higher the borate concentration, the more preferably DHA yielded. Next, the impact of the glycerol concentration on the GEOR process and product distribution was subsequently examined by conducting GEOR with three different glycerol concentrations (0.1, 1.0, and 2.0 M) in a fixed 0.1 M borate electrolyte. An increase in glycerol concentration led to both a reduction in current density and a positive shift in the onset potential, as depicted in Fig. 5 d. The increasing glycerol concentration resulted in a higher viscosity of the electrolyte, which hindered the efficient transportation of ions to and from the electrode surface. Although the solution was gently stirred to enhance mass transport, the influence of glycerol concentration was still apparent, indicating that the restricted mass transport greatly impacted the rate of electrochemical reaction and current density [17]. During 3 h GEOR at 1.75 VRHE, the liquid products were collected and analyzed using HPLC. As shown in Fig. 5 e and Fig. S10 , three main products, DHA, GLYD, and FA, and three minor products, TART, GLAC, and GLCO, were detected. Increasing the concentration of glycerol resulted in a decrease in both the yield of product and the selectivity of the 3C product. Specifically, GLYD emerged as a dominant product with the rise in glycerol concentration, and its selectivity reached a peak, representing 51 % at a glycerol concentration of 1.0 M. Conversely, the selectivity of DHA decreased as the concentration of glycerol increased, resulting in a decline from 35.1 % at 0.1 M glycerol to 20.1 % at 2.0 M glycerol. The GLAC selectivity was found to decline along with a slight increase in FA selectivity. No GLCO or TART was detected at 1.0 M and 2.0 M glycerol samples. The yield of product at different glycerol concentrations was measured and illustrated in Fig. 5 f and Fig. S10 . The total yield of product dropped significantly when glycerol concentration reached 2.0 M. The yield of DHA and FA decreased from 21.4 to 1.9 μmole, and from 13 to 2.3 μmole when glycerol concentration increased from 0.1 M to 2.0 M, respectively. In contrast, the yield of GLYD reached a peak at 1.0 M glycerol, accounted for 25.9 μmole, then dropped significantly to 4.9 μmole at 2.0 M glycerol. These data demonstrated how varying glycerol concentrations influenced DHA and GLYD selectivity. In addition, the total FE (Fig. 5 f and Table S5 ) for GEOR was found to be slightly increased when increasing glycerol concentration, accounting for 60.2, 66.7 and 76.9 % for electrolytes containing 0.1, 1.0, and 2.0 M glycerol, respectively. The data derived from varying glycerol concentrations demonstrated that GLYD preferred yielding when increasing glycerol concentration. The high glycerol concentration made the increase in total FE, but with the cost of decreasing the contents of 3C product and current density. Based on the HPLC analysis, DHA or GLYD could be obtained as a primary product by varying the concentration of borate or glycerol. To further demonstrate the selective oxidation of the primary or secondary alcohol group, two electrolytes, including borate-dominant solution (0.15 M borate and 0.1 M glycerol, denoted as B/G-1.5, based on the ratio of borate to glycerol) and glycerol dominant solution (0.1 M borate and 1.0 M glycerol, denoted as B/G-0.1) were employed to conduct GEOR at 1.75 VRHE. The J-V curves in Fig. S11 a disclosed that the B/G-1.5 electrolyte achieved higher current density than that of the B/G-0.1 electrolyte, probably due to the higher viscosity of the B/G-0.1 solution, which was accompanied by the lower charge transfer resistance in of B/G-1.5 electrolyte, as depicted in Fig. S11 b and Table S6 . The recorded J-t curves at 1.75 VRHE in Fig. S11 c indicated that oxidation activity in both electrolytes could be maintained during monitor reaction time. The liquid product and yield of product analysis after 3 h GEOR (Fig. 6 a and Fig. S12 ) depicted that the 3C product was the major product, with selectivity of ∼ 80 % in both cases. The dominant product in the B/G-1.5 electrolyte was DHA, which constituted 39.5 % of the total selectivity, whereas, in the B/G-0.1 electrolyte, GLYD was the principal product, with a selectivity of 45.6 %. The average amount of DHA (Fig. 6 b) in the B/G-1.5 electrolyte (25.9 μmole) was approximately 1.6 times higher than that in the B/G-0.1 electrolyte (16 μmole). Meanwhile, GEOR in the B/G-0.1 electrolyte generated 22.4 μmole GLYD, which was 1.2 times higher than that in the B/G-1.5 electrolyte. The total FE in B/G-1.5 (59.8 %) was slightly lower than that in B/G-0.1 electrolyte (66.9 %). In addition, the carbon balance for GEOR was around 98 % for both electrolytes ( Table S7 ), suggesting that insignificant intermediates were escaping from the HPLC sampling and analysis. Overall, the data obtained from two working conditions further confirmed selectivity towards DHA and GLYD could be altered by manipulating electrolyte composition. When dissolving in water, Na2B4O7 hydrolyzes to B(OH)3 and [B(OH)4 -] [38,58]; the pH of the borate solution depends on the borate concentration. When pH is higher than 9, [B(OH)4 -] ion content is dominant [58], and [B(OH)4 -] is favorable to react with glycerol, forming anion complexes and releasing H+, which causes decreasing solution pH. Therefore, the pH drop could be considered an indicator of borate-glycerol ester formation in borate buffer [59,60]. The pH of borate buffers with and without glycerol was measured and displayed in Tables S8 and S9 . The introduction of glycerol into the borate buffer caused a drop in the pH of the solutions, specifically in relation to the initial borate concentration. This indicated the potential presence of borate-glycerol complexes in the solution. The increase in borate or glycerol concentration resulted in a greater pH drop, suggesting that borate-glycerol complexes favored forming at high borate or glycerol concentration. Such anion complexes could not only provide alcohol group protection but also migrate to anode better than charge-neutral glycerol molecule, hence enhanced selectivity towards 3C product and GEOR performance [26], in accordance with the results derived from varying borate concentration in Fig. 4. It is widely accepted that the oxidation of primary or secondary alcohol groups of glycerol generated GLYD and DHA, respectively [10,11,26]. The data above demonstrated that tuning the borate/glycerol (B/G) ratio could insulate oxidation towards primary or secondary. In principle, borate could form five-member and six-member ring chelates with 1,2-diols and 1,3-diols, respectively. Various complexes, including borate-glycerol mono-chelate (1:1) and bis-chelate (1:2), have been reported for borate-polyol anion coordinates ( Fig. S13 ) [61–63]. To get further evidence of complex formation, Raman spectra of electrolytes with various borate/glycerol ratio were recorded. As illustrated in Fig. 7 a and Fig. S14 a-b, when introducing borate in 0.1 M glycerol solution, a new band corresponding to the breathing vibration of the six-member ring borate-glycerol complex appeared at 834 cm−1 [61], and this band became more intensive along with the rise of B/G ratio. These findings suggested that six-member ring complex favored forming when increasing B/G ratio. In contracts, when adding glycerol in 0.1 M borate solution (Fig. 7 b and Fig. S14 c-d), the B–O stretching band at 733 cm−1 shifted to 758 cm−1, confirming the formation of the five-member ring borate-glycerol complex [29,61]. The higher glycerol concentration, the more intensive this band is, suggesting five-member ring chelate favored forming when decreasing B/G ratio. When B/G ratio increased, six-member ring 1,3-glycerol-borate complexes became dominant, whereas decreasing B/G ratio led to the dominance of the five-member ring 1,2-glycerol-borate complexes. The Raman data suggested that manipulating the B/G ratio could impact the proportion of five- and six-member ring complexes in the electrolyte; hence, selectively oxidizing primary and secondary alcohol groups could be controlled, resulting in the production of GLYD or DHA as the primary product. To verify the effect of the B/G ratio on the variation of DHA and GLYD selectivity, FTIR was employed to detect the difference in glycerol-surface binding mode after soaking activated NiOx electrode in two investigated electrolytes B/G-1.5 and B/G-0.1. As illustrated in Fig. 7 c, although two NiOx samples showed similar transmittance spectra, some variation could be observed at the spectral region of 1000 –1100 cm−1. The bands at 1064 and 1025 cm−1 could be assigned to C–OH stretching mode derived from primary and secondary –OH of glycerol adsorbed on NiOx surface [12,15,64]. The intensity of the C–OH stretching mode emanating from the secondary –OH group was notably higher in the sample using B/G-1.5 electrolyte, whereas this mode of the primary –OH group was more pronounced in the sample using B/G-0.1 electrolyte. The variation in adsorption configuration is likely anticipated to modify the selective oxidation of the primary and secondary –OH group, leading to the preferential formation of certain products, resulting in the difference of observed GYD and DHA selectivity. At this stage, the mechanism of five- or six-member ring complex formation regarding the different B/G ratio is still unclear due to the complicated factors that affect the complex formation, such as competitive coordinating between water and glycerol, interconversion between five- and six-member complexes, or intramolecular hydrogen bonding in the polyol [28,65]. A comprehensive understanding of this mechanism would require a thorough theoretical inspection later on. The tentative reaction pathway based on the factors governing GEOR on NiOx when varying B/G ratio in borate buffer electrolyte was illustrated in Fig. 8 . When introducing glycerol to borate buffer, various glycerol borate ester complexes form equilibrium in pH 9 solution. Manipulating the B/G ratio could affect equilibrium, hence changing the predominant complex forming in the solution. In high B/G ratio (∼1.5) electrolyte, the favorable forming six-member ring chelate enhanced the adsorption of secondary –OH group, which resulted in selective oxidation secondary –OH group and generated DHA as the main product. In the low B/G ratio (∼0.1) electrolyte, the dominant formation of five-member chelate improved the adsorption of primary –OH group, leading to favorable oxidation of primary –OH group and yielding GLYD as the major product. GLYD would then be oxidized further to GLAC, which could then be gradually oxidized to TART as the potential increased [66]. At high applied potential, GLCO, a product generated from breaking C–C bonds of GLAC, would also be detected. It should be noted that FA was present at all investigated potentials even when GLCO was absent. This finding revealed that the presence of FA in product distribution might contribute to direct C–C cleavage from glycerol, which was consistent with prior studies [12,16]. 4 Conclusion In summary, we comprehensively investigated how manipulating the borate/glycerol ratio affected the glycerol electrooxidation process on amorphous NiOx catalyst in borate buffer (pH 9.2). The enhanced selectivity towards 3C product, especially for DHA and GLYD, contributed to borate-polyols complex formation, which is confirmed by electrochemical and HPLC analysis. After optimizing working conditions, DHA was the main product, achieving ∼ 39.5 % in high B/G ratio (∼1.5) electrolyte, while GLYD was the major product in the low B/G ratio (∼0.1) electrolyte, with a selectivity of ∼ 45.6 %. Raman spectroscopy disclosed that the six-member ring chelate became dominant at high B/G ratio, whereas the five-member ring chelate preferred forming at low B/G ratio. With different B/G ratios, the formation of these borate-polyol complexes could modify the adsorption behavior of glycerol on the catalyst surface, hence altering the selective oxidation of the secondary or primary alcohol group, leading to generating DHA or GLYD as the dominant product. The results in this study not only highlight the comprehensive mechanistic understanding of selective glycerol electrooxidation towards primary or secondary alcohol but also develop a simple strategy to obtain highly valuable products at near-neutral pH levels, which is universally applicable to other transition metal electrocatalysts. coredata.dc:description: Controlling selective glycerol electrooxidation towards the primary or secondary alcohol group, which enables obtained dihydroxyacetone or glyceraldehyde as the main product, is a challenge for an effective glycerol electrolysis system. In this work, we systematically investigated the protective effect of borate-glycerol complexes toward primary and secondary alcohol group oxidation during the glycerol electrooxidation process on NiOx catalyst in borate buffer (pH 9.2). The Raman spectroscopy and high-performance liquid chromatography results indicated that manipulating the borate/glycerol (B/G) ratio could affect selective oxidation towards primary or secondary alcohol group. Five-member ring complex was more likely to form in the electrolyte with the B/G ratio of 0.1, whereas six-member ring complex became more significant in the electrolyte with the B/G ratio of 1.5. The dominance of five- or six-member ring complex could enhance the favored adsorption of primary or secondary alcohol group, thus generating glyceraldehyde or dihydroxyacetone as the main product, respectively. The results in this study highlight the significance of electrolyte property on glycerol electrocatalysis, which is universally applicable to other transition metal electrocatalysts, enabling the development of a highly selective glycerol electrooxidation towards primary or secondary alcohol system at near-neutral pH level.
